The rooms were lovely with beautiful hard wood floors, exposed brick walls, updated bathroom, high ceilings, that led out to a private patio. The staff leaves out afternoon tea, snacks, cake, peach flavored water, and cookies and milk before bed.  The inn is across from Chatham square, near forsythe park and a short walking distance from everything that beautiful Savannah has to offer. We will definitely be returning and I would highly recommend this to family and friends.Not impressed. We paid $169 for one night and have had better hotel rooms with free breakfast for half the price. My husband and I stayed in the Mercer room. The bath tub felt like it was going to fall through the floor and it was extremely slippery even with the slip proof mat in the tub. The water went from scalding hot to ice cold with no middle ground. The bed was very uncomfortable and there is rather small. The bed frame is way larger than the mattress so you can't help but smash your legs on it, I have many bruises. The overall ambiance is very nice. I loved the historic feel of the building and the room. We had a back door to our room that went out onto a roof patio that had stairs down to the breakfast patio which was very cute. The staff members were very friendly and helpful. Breakfast was underwhelming. I got the egg white omelette (delicious) that came with toast (one piece of dry wheat bread, had to ask for butter) and a side of seasonal fruit (the smallest piece of watermelon I've ever seen... I've had larger "sides of fruit" in a cocktail). My husband also received dry toasted bread and had to ask twice for the bacon and sausage that was supposed to come with his breakfast. I would not stay here again, especially for the price. Rather disappointed.Love this B&B in Savannah.  Great location and good accommodations.We really enjoyed our 4 nights here. The B&B operates a dozen or so units on the block which were formerly separates attached residences. We stayed on the second floor of a renovated carriage house (Camellia Room) and found it quite charming. Very spacious rooms, comfortable beds, quiet and somewhat frou frou old timey decor. Room wasn't particularly dark if that is a major concern for you.A series of cute well-planted courtyards connect many of the rooms and several cats laze about all day. Staff was very attentive and friendly. We enjoyed the quick breakfast service, as well as the complementary afternoon tea and chocolate chip cookies in the evening! We ate our breakfast on the back deck overlooking the courtyard, sunlight filtering through the big moss-covered oaks and loquat trees. Location is fantastic. It's right on Chatham Square, 90 second walk to Bull street and Forsythe Park. Good food in the area too with Mrs. Wilke's and Crystal Beer Parlor right around the corner. We didn't have a car until the last day, but the staff apparently pays your metered parking from 8-11AM so you don't have to wake up early! Only downside was the wifi was spotty at times.Overall very pleasant experience. It's not the most luxurious spot so don't come expecting posh, but its more than adequate and really quite charming. Would stay here again and highly recommend. Did I mention the free cookies?No complaints here! We stayed in the Tomochichi room for two nights last weekend here. The room is actually named after the native american chief that originally sold the land Savannah was built on to General Oglethorpe. Actually all of the rooms at the inn are named after something historic in Savannah. Kind of a neat little thing if you're into the history of the city. Checking in was a breeze. Joey helped us get situated promptly, including a short tour of the inn and it's amenities. We were quickly in out room and settled. The room itself was pretty awesome. Most of it was old exposed brick on one side and the other had several windows and door facing the center patio of the inn. The room was decorated eloquently and it really felt like an older, rustic room, with modern amenities of course. The adjacent patio was really nice, with a garden and plenty of shade, and plenty of cats! This is where we ate breakfast both mornings. I really enjoyed the location of this place. It's right next to Forsyth park which is beautiful. It's also a short walk to River Street, crossing trough several of the squares. It's an even shorter cab ride back, if you've been on RIver Street too long.I'll definitely be returning for another stay here.What a gem! The rooms are beautiful, staff is    extremely nice and helpful, and they have gingerbread and brownies waiting for you. I couldn't be more pleased.Tons of character and way quieter than the riverfront, which is only a 10 minute walk away.We stayed two nights with the Summer Special. The first night we were in the Red Cottage. It was a fantastic two-story with living space downstairs (with a pull out couch and two chairs for seating and a mini fridge and microwave). The sleeping area and bath were upstairs.  The second night,  we're in the Azalea room, which consisted of two rooms. One room had a nice seating area with two chairs and it had the bathroom.  The second room had a bed, a couple of tables, and a smaller chair. Both rooms were nicely decorated and clean. Check out their pictures, not doing it justice. Also, the staff was very friendly and made suggestions on things to do and places to eat. The breakfasts were delicious and be sure to try the afternoon tea and the milk/cookies!We stayed in the Camellia room (up the stairs, through the dining room, out the back door, down the stairs into the courtyard, up the stairs to our own private building) and it was almost perfect.  The room was spacious, the bed comfortable, the temperature controls spot on.  The location is in the middle of the historic district, with everything we wanted to see within a short walk (the tourist area along the river was about 20 minutes walk but enough said about that place).  The staff was friendly and helpful.  The breakfast choices were superb.  Parking is on the street, but there were plenty of spaces and the Inn provides a permit to put on the dashboard - free parking.We stayed for 3 nights and thoroughly enjoyed it.What was less than perfect?  Nothing serious.  The shower was almost hot enough, and the wifi a bit weak.  All things considered I would recommend this place to anyone.This was a "I'm passing through on a road trip" stay.  And it was nice.  An old traditional Savannah row home that was charming and the staff was helpful.They are a little walk down to the water, but the walk moves you through a few nice parks and neighborhoods.The rooms are large and comfortable and noise from other rooms isn't an issue.Breakfast is included and I'd recommend getting there early or right near the end to not be crowded or wait for seating.All and all a great alternative to hotel/motels.We were staying in the Live Oaks suite. It was very spacious and is at the end of the street overlooking Chatham square. It had a private entrance right on the street so it was like having a whole house to yourself. The room also had a microwave, fridge, and coffee pot. The queen bed firm but comfortable. Would have liked some fluffier pillows. The water pressure was nice in the shower. The bathroom is off the bedroom. Breakfast the was very good and portions were filling. They gave you 2-3 different options and the previous day you fill out a card letting them know which option you want. The bnb will also schedule tours for you and place them on your "tab". The concierge was very helpful with suggestions. I highly recommend and we will def be back. For the price you can't beat it for your own place downtown.Stayed here two summers ago and it was absolutely wonderful. The staff was amazing, the room was clean and comfortable, and the breakfast was very good. Within walking distance to Forsyth Park which is absolutely gorgeous and if you like walking it's a very beautiful walk to almost any location. Also extremely easy to get to Tybee Island from here.I loved it here so much, I'm going back this summer and taking my fiance. I can't wait, I'm so excited!
review_content_20: This place is just adorable. Our accommodations were elegant, comfortable (oh, those beds!), and clean. I stayed in "Mercer," which has one pro that is also a con: it is very quiet, but its view isn't great. It looks out over a roof and courtyard, not Chatham Square. I much prefer this however, because I can't enjoy a view from my bed as I'm tossing and turning due to traffic noise. The only other negative from my room was that I had no hot water for my evening shower (at 11 pm).The public spaces are beautifully done and well looked after. Breakfast was delicious and a vegetarian option was offered. Staff were friendly and helpful. All-in-all, I'll definitely be back on my next trip to Savannah.We enjoyed our stay. The location is fantastic. I suggest you stay in one of the carriage houses, or cottages, if you would like more privacy. The breakfasts were amazing. Both days our food was delicious, unique, and the portions were generous. We had the pleasure of speaking with the chef, he was very nice and even gave me his sauce recipe after I complimented it. We live in atlanta and look forward to coming back soon, this place is perfect for quiet weekend getaways.Great service, Hugh rooms...suites. Clean. Good breakfast, would stay again. They even have dehumidifiers. Our unit had a kitchen too. Live Oak is very nice and comfortable.PERFECT LOCATION! We wanted to be far away from the cheesy Riverfront...this is the place! Jasper house was great, and the breakfasts were delicious. Heaven for walking.... Great shops and restaurants were close....a true Savannah experience!!Great location, they paid for parking, and the room was clean. However, we really wanted to like this place more than we did because the website oversold it a bit. The room was ok but the service was not nearly as friendly as indicated on the other reviews. The most disappointing aspect was the food. We expected it to be more gourmet and instead received food we could have made ourselves at home. Even the cookies at night were just ok. It was also a little off putting to see tip jars everywhere in the dining room, mentioned it in the welcome sheet and an envelope for tips in the room. We expect to tip the housekeeping staff but usually the owners or innkeepers handle breakfast. This is really more of a small hotel acting as a bed and breakfast. Also beware that the stairs are steep and narrow if you have mobility problems.This place was very average, food was just Ok, staff is helpful. This facility lacks strong management and organization. The rooms are surface clean.I was under a little stress to find a nice place to stay for this trip. My boyfriend had a meeting he had to attend and put me in charge of finding a hotel a month in advance. Of course, almost all of the bed and breakfasts in Savannah were booked and the ones that were available for far too expensive.I felt very optimistic about this place as the reviews were good and the price was not too high. It was also extremely close to the location of my boyfriend's meeting.Shortly before our trip I received a last minute notice that cause our arrival time in Savannah to be pushed back. I was so glad to know that there would be someone to let us in, even after hours.We arrived at 11 p.m. and a kind woman showed us around the inn, gave us our keys and showed us our room. I felt so bad about being late but she immediately made me feel at ease!Breakfast was wonderful. I think my boyfriend would have preferred to have more than one choice each morning, but it did not bother me too badly.Despite previous reviews, I did not find the coffee to be bad at all, maybe it's improved!After we got settled in our room, we went out for a midnight walk which was wonderful. The inn is located seconds from Forsyth Park, so it's much quieter than River Street and areas closer to the river.We stayed in the Mercer room, which was much prettier than it looked in the pictures. The bed was comfortable and there was plenty of room to stretch out for a couple of days. It is up one flight of narrow stairs, so I don't suggest bringing large suitcases (fortunately we pack light!). The walls are a little thin, but our neighbors were very quiet.We didn't spend too much time at the inn, but when we were there it felt wonderful. It was so delightful to sit with other guests at breakfast, snack on milk and cookies right before bed and sit out on the patio during the evenings. I cannot attest to the afternoon tea, but I'm sure it was lovely, as was everything else at this place.I would definitely recommend this place to anyone looking for a good bed and breakfast in Savannah. It isn't as expensive as the rest and the staff is amazing.Comfy beds, cookies and milk, eggs Benedict for breakfast. I'm a happy gal!Gorgeous little B&B. I have never stayed at one of these before so I don't have anything to compare it to. However, this was a gem of place to stay at. I stayed in the Egyptian room. It was cute and cozy with Egyptian artwork purposefully placed in all the right places. The bed was big and comfy with pillows that resembled fluffy clouds at the end of a long day of walking through Savannah. I could not have asked for a better place to stay at. Best part-- Afternoon cookies and tea!!! However, the cookies actually turned out to be cheesecake brownies (even better than cookies!!!!). I can't comment on the night time milk and cookies because we were not back in time for that. My only recommendation for this place is for them to consider playing background music throughout the Inn. It was so quiet all the time that I always felt like I needed to whisper when I was roaming the grounds. Also, they need to work on their coffee. It was so weak! Tasted like coffee-water, blehhh.I don't frequent B&B's very often, so maybe this stuff is all normal to those that do...but several things about this place bugged me.#1 - The room (we stayed in The Jasmine) was dusty and the bedsheets and blanket were covered in small yellow food stains. It as gross and we asked for new sheets.#2 - There was a huge (and I mean HUGE) hole in the wall that broadcast voices and the AC vent noises all night. The owners obviously tried to hide it by placing a table in front of the hole, but you could still see it while walking around the room.#3 - The decor in the common room and our bedroom was similar to an old ladies house - lots of dust, doilies, heavy furniture and kitschy trinkets. #5 - I came back with some crazy large bugs in my clothes from when I set them on a chair...gross!#4 The rooms had a stale smell, like mothballs and old grease.HOWEVER....The front desk guy was really friendly, and the location was gorgeous. You could walk to great restaurants and nearby parks, and it was on a very quiet street.My fiance and I also really liked the back porch, where we sipped some wine and watched a passing thunderstorm...very relaxing!All in all I was a bit disappointed, especially given the great photos and reviews I'd seen online.This establishment had a very dirty bathroom floor in the Masters Suite (my socks stuck to the "tacky" floor). They did not respond to my e-mail addressing that concern and the fact that they did not comply with the terms of the LivingSocial deal (with a "premium" room a bottle of champagne was to be included). A simple response from this establishment would have been appreciated, but as they did not even bother to respond at all, I conclude that customer satisfaction is not high on their priority. So bottom line is ... avoid Savannah B&B.We really enjoyed our stay at the Savannah Bed and Breakfast Inn! It was so nice. We stayed in the lane cottage and it was very private, which we liked. I left a bunch of clothes in a drawer on accident and they called me almost immediately after and held onto them for me until I could come back to get them. I thought that was great customer service.Breakfast was good and the ambience is very nice. We felt very fancy staying there! I'd definitely recommend staying. They offer a budget stay where you can just pay a lower price per night and not choose where you'll be staying, and bedandbreakfast.com offers a lot of deals that can help you knock even more off the price!I loved the Inn. All of the staff was friendly.There was also street parking that the hotel will pay for, but you do have to look at the signs to make sure the street sweeper isn't coming that night.The Ivy Cottage is fantastic! The small spiral staircase might not be for everyone, but we loved it! The cottage had the bathroom and bedroom on the first floor, and the living room and kitchenette upstairs. There was a great balcony right off the living room. The bed was kind of high, but it was comfy. I'm really picky about the bed, and this was really good. The cottage was clean, and delightfully eclectic. The kitchenette had a sink, coffee maker (with coffee,tea and supplies), a microwave, mini fridge and utensils. Having the flexibility to choose what time frame(7:00-9:30) we wanted to eat breakfast, was a plus. The cook was super friendly, always coming to see what else he could do for you, and the wait staff was also fantastic. They have a snack and tea in the evening, and fresh baked cookies at 8. My 18 year old daughter and I were so impressed with everything.We had stayed at the Doubletree in July, but we much prefer the Inn. I will definitely stay here again, I can't wait!I chose this place over a place I had stayed before and for over $200 a night I really wanted to love this place. All-in-all my experience seemed a contradiction in terms. It's much larger an operation than the traditional B&B - almost a wannabe boutique hotel. Perhaps it's going through growing pains which might explain why they're trying too hard or not enough. Following some confusion over my reservation (which was handled brilliantly and professionally - actually all the evening desk clerks were friendly and helpful) I was shown to a very nice room, where insulated windows was appreciated as I was on the street side. The blinds didn't do much to keep out street lamp light, however. The room was comfortable in spite of too much faux antique furniture but he Internet worked right away which was a plus. I had concern with the lack of hot water. There was the usual card for saving water by hanging up towels, yet after 10 minutes of trying to get hot water (both days) I gave up and went for the cold shower (maybe hot water cost extra). Breakfast was also odd -- all this wait staff hovering like a fine dining room yet the first morning I had to explain my order ticket (name and a couple of check off boxes). I was concerned it was me, but then I heard someone else explain an order that seemed super simple. The grits were amazing and the eggs benedict ok. The ham was the rectangular packaged lunchmeat and I couldn't cut the English muffin (sigh). Day two I scheduled the first seating and had to leave without eating because the food wasn't ready and I had to get on the road. So the kicker to all this was the tip jars and tip envelopes everywhere. Extremely off-putting (especially since the trash in my room wasn't emptied - could have made my own bed). A lot of things not consistent with traditional B&Bs. Probably will go back to my other place next time.This was a nice B&B---though somewhat industrial (i.e. large). I guess the size helps them offer the B&B amenities at scale, and thus keep prices down.The top floor room that we stayed in was nicely decorated and spacious. It had a TV in the room and a roomy private bathroom. Two large bedroom windows overlooked the square. The location of this B&B is excellent. The square it is on is beautiful and quiet and it is within walking distance of everything in historic Savannah. The reason why I knocked one star off was the breakfasts; in one word: awful. Both mornings we unfortunately opted for the hot breakfasts. The B&B breakfasts made Waffle House look gourmet and high quality (this is not a dig on Waffle House... I love Waffle House). Unless you inquire and they tell you they have re-done their breakfast menu, opt for the cold breakfast (yogurt, cereal, fruit, and coffee). The juice they served with breakfast was horrid (tasted worse than watery tang) and I can make a better hot breakfast in my sleep. The one place this B&B cheaped out (and shouldn't have) was on breakfast. Beds and rooms were great. Breakfast could have used a slight budget boost per person to bring it up to par with what you would expect from any self respecting B&B. In fact... simple eggs, toast, fruit, and good coffee would beat out what they tried to pass off as a 'fancy' breakfast.Free parking was a great perk. Free wifi was nice (though it was a bit of a struggle to get my computer to connect; I had better luck downstairs than up in the bedroom).It must have been destiny because my girl friend found this place 2 months before St. Patty's Day when most everything was sold out in the Historic District or way overpriced. We stayed in the Ivy Cottage and loved the suite. It was a small two story place with the bedroom on the ground floor and the living room/kitchen upstairs. A steep spiral staircase made it all the more fun. The rooms were clean and AC worked just fine. Silverware, plates, glasses were all provided with a mini fridge. And there was a flat panel TV with the basic cable stations...We only had the breakfast once but it was apart of the buffet and was good. Not sure why there are complaints but if you need something in the early AM, it works. Plus you should be out eating the local cuisine in Savannah and not getting stuffed at a Bed and Breakfast, right? Shoot , morning of St. Patty's they served wine and juice...awesome!The B&B is a fun 15 minute walk to the river but with all the things to see, you won't even notice the time. And coming home at night after partying was great...it was like staying at grandmas because the main lobby would have cookies and water or ice tea left over...can't beat that! But it is a bed and breakfast so if you are the rowdy type, don't go, but if you are coupled up, this place is as good as it gets.I hesitate to write this review because I don't want everyone finding out about this gem! BUT, lucky for you, I believe in spreading good news. I love staying at this inn. The building and rooms are beautiful and well kept, the staff is super friendly, and the morning breakfast is delicious and homemade! I love sitting in the courtyard having tea and fresh omlets.The location too is perfect. This square is not the most beautiflu in Savannah, but it's lovely and only steps from Mercer House and Forsyth Park.The most amazing part is the price though... I cannot believe a place like this exists that is so affordable. But don't let the affordability throw you off: this place is every bit as good (and perhaps better!) than its more expensive counterparts.Excellent for the price. Great staff. We had the Ivy Cottage, a great room with bed and bath downstairs, and a tight spiral staircase leading to a kitchenette, living room and balcony. Not the room for you if you can't do stairs. Breakfast wasn't special, but enough to start the day. Anyway, you want your appetite in tact for all that Savannah has to offer.Tea and snacks in the afternoon and milk and cookies before bed add a nice touch.Location may seem far from the river, but you don't want to miss all that you'll see on the walk. I'll stay here again.Our first bed and breakfast experience, and it was such a great one. Our room was very nice and had a great view (the Parkview room), and I even started to enjoy the walk up the two flights of stairs to get there. My mom rented the only other room on that floor, so it was very homey feeling. The four poster bed was very comfortable, and the exposed beams and the old furnishings made the ambiance something wonderful.The Inn is located close to EVERYTHING. Savannah's downtown/historic district is small and totally walkable, so staying at the Bed and Breakfast Inn was a treat. We were able to walk to the Sentient Bean in the morning for coffee (at the other end of Forsyth Park), grab a new toothbrush at Brighter Days Natural Foods, and then head back down to the waterfront very quickly.The staff were all extremely nice and accommodating. Bob, the owner, has many great stories to part with, and you are taken great care of. We especially loved the nightly milk and cookies, and the weekend wine and hors d'oeuvres. The daily breakfast is cooked fresh and is often shared with other guests around one of the big wooden tables. A great way to get to know some of the other folks enjoying the B&B with you.This is not the type of place for people who don't like interacting with other guests or engaging in conversations. This is a very social place and all the better for it! We spent Christmas night playing trivial pursuit and chatting with other guests over milk and cookies.If we come back to Savannah, we will definitely stay here again!First off - I am a dodo. I made my reservation for last thursday. The guy asked me for my name, I told him, he said he couldn't find me. I looked at the confirmation email - it had us checking in last week. We stared awkwardly at each other and I asked if he could honor it since it was already paid. He said that he would. Whew! And we booked the mgr. special so we had no idea what we would get but ended up in the Ivy Cottage. The inn is nice, the dining room is standard fare I'd say. A dead charming courtyard in the back. Super cute. The Ivy Cottage is separate from the main house which is nice. The bedroom is very European sized, if you know what I mean. The bathroom had just a shower but was a very decent size. A spiral stair leads you to a sitting area with a kitchenette and a little balcony that overlooks the courtyard.For breakfast, you fill out a card and in the morning they ask you your room so they can bring you your meal. Fine by me. They offered grapefruit juice so I was happy. Selection wasn't huge but it was definitely wide enough. Location is great too. No, it's not on Bull and LIberty but, as a native of Savannah, this is the more charming area of town anyways.I loved the location and the overall feel of the B&B but the filling out a card for your breakfast the night before and not having room for everyone to sit down for breakfast was a letdown. The rooms where nice, the bed felt ok and the bathrooms where newer. But the rooms needed to be cleaned maybe a little better for my taste. I think the night staff guy was nice he walked around and knew who you were. The day front desk lady was impersonal and didn't know what was going on. A suggestion if you're going to spend some time here pack two small suitcases if you're on the third floor it'll kill you carrying up a large suitcase up narrow stairs. I would also bring wet wipes. Savannah was fun and beautiful you really don't spend that much time at the B&B anyway. -T 8-)
review_content_40: Very nice option for staying in downtown Savannah.  Our room (Pulaski) had great working A/C (still needed in November), and was nice and quiet.The bathroom could be better, and they could have been a little more generous with the towels and whatnot.Breakfast was big and tasty, totally satisfied.Savannah Bed and Breakfast Inn is a little gem in the heart of the historic district situated across from Chatam Square was the perfect starting location to explore Savannah.  I stumbled upon this B&B after doing some Internet searches.  I ultimately went for this particular B&B due to value.  I was able to get a room for $99/night.  Quite a bargain for the historic district.  Not only was breakfast included but I also considered the following a bonus: paid parking, afternoon tea & baked goods, evening cookies and milk.  My room the Telfair, was simply charming in decoration.  Located on the second floor this might pose a challenge for some not comfortable with stairs.  I, however, would hesitate to recommend as the room looked out on to the square and was high enough to be sheltered from any street traffic noise.In the spirit of full disclosure, there were several items not quite to my liking that prevent me from giving a higher rating.  1.  There are multiple cats that call the outside deck/courtyard home.  I am extremely allergic to cats so these areas of the property were off limits to me and anyone else who has dander allergies.  2. I also found it slightly odd that this B&B didn't have a formal living room receiving room. The majority of the common space was taken up with breakfast tables.  So, outside of sitting outside or a table there was little space to escape your room.  3. The free Internet signal is not available in all rooms and in the Telfair the signal was extremely weak.  Also,  If you are a B&B breakfast snob, this is not the location for you.  The breakfasts were good but nothing special to write home about.  I stayed 3 days and the best option was the pancakes served on my last day.That being said, I would stay here again in a heartbeat.  The accommodations and service were top notch and this far outweighs any slight inconveniences.The Savannah Bed & Breakfast Inn is a charming little B&B on a beautiful tree-lined street with relatively easy street parking.  They give you a parking pass so you can park for free at any meter in the city, as well as selected parking garages, so it's also convenient.  Our room was small but cute--the only complaint we had was the extremely hard bed, with hard pillows to match.  However, the delicious breakfast each morning somewhat made up for that.  Everything is homemade and fresh--the highlight for me were the addictive cheese grits and buttery mushroom quiche.  Even better were the fresh-baked, warm chocolate chip cookies that were left out each night around 8pm.  There was also a wine and cheese hour between 5-7pm.The staff are sweet and helpful, and it's located close to pretty much anything you'd want to do in Savannah.Nice little inn in a great location. It's about a 15 minute walk to the riverside. The room was clean and had the expected historic charm you'd expect in Savannah. Granted this isn't the Ritz Carlton of bed&breakfasts though, so don't expect anything extremely fancy. The staff was very friendly and accommodating. The breakfast every morning was excellent. It'll be on the top of my list when we go back.Super sweet people, awesome chocolate chip cookies, cute inn, great location. The bummers were: the coffee was awful - ugh. The bed really wasn't that comfortable and you could easily hear people walking by your room. Overall good deal for the price.Ok, granted that this is was my first Bed & Breakfast stay BUT, I was highly impressed with this place. My future Mother in Law spent 3 wonderful nights and 4 days! Everything was immaculate! And the service was superb! Milk and cookies at night and wonderful breakfast! Our rooms had the most gorgeous and intricately carved wooden beds, feather pillows and softest sheets I have slept on in a loooong time! My only complaint was, the bathroom. Its very small and oddly put together. I am a bathroom freak. I love for a room I stay in to flow and it seems off. But then again it can be expected if its an old house turned into a bed and breakfast. It was also close to everything I wanted to walk to and it was wonderful walking all of historic Savanna and not have to worry about parking! I really really really want to stay here again as soon as my fiance comes off deployment and visits!A seriously magical bed.Ready for too much information?Good.I got up in the night to pee twice and both times thought I wouldn't get back to sleep, but each time my head hit that pillow?  Zonk, right back under I went.This place surprised us in how gorgeous it was.  The house, the rooms, the furniture... even the breakfast was amazing.  Savannah certainly is the hostess-city!  The owner came by in the morning, introduced himself and asked if everything was all right.  It was just perfect. It is also right by Forsyth park, which makes for a nice, picturesque early morning jog or walk.Great location away from the tourist crowds but still close enough walk to shops and restaurants. Typical B&B decor in that it's very fancy...and dated. Breakfast was good. Cookies were great. Good value for the money. But beware, checkout time is at 10am!!!Our favorite place to stay in Savannah.  Just a half block or so behind the Mercer House, and tucked away next to a quiet square.  They offer pretty reasonable rates, especially during the slow season.  It's laid back and a great place for those that aren't totally into the "Bed and Breakfast Experience" as there is a bit more privacy.We have stayed their 3 times, and are planning our next trip in a few months.A sweet little BnB, great location and very helpful staff. Breakfast was average, nothing special and in fact if I went again, I would rather venture out to try something new and yummy instead of wasting a meal there. Short walk to the water, gives the opportunity to wander and explore. It felt like staying at your grandma's house-- weak AC, lots of clutter and kitch, old but clean bathrooms, old beds, old blankets. This was my first BnB experience and probably my last. I personally prefer the uniformity and cleanliness of chain hotels. We stayed in the Tea Olive which was HORRIBLE (right under the stairs, could hear everything going on upstairs and outside) and the Tomochichi (better location in the courtyard).Just returned from my first visit to Savannah and I would love to go back soon!  This Inn was a wonderful, affordable place in a beautiful city.The Inn is located on W. Gordon between Chatham and Monterey Squares. It is a picturesque row of houses, with curved stairways and wrought iron railings, on a tree-lined street. The location is great. It is easy walking distance to all the squares and to beautiful Forsythe Park.  About 15 -20 minute walk to River Street.Four of us stayed in the Jasper House, which is a lovely three story row house. It has four bedrooms and 2 1/2 baths, remodeled kitchen, living room, formal dining room, and formal parlor (even has a chandelier).  The rooms were very spacious, very nicely decorated, and very comfortable. The house has a very "period" feel, yet all the modern amenities , including washer and dryer. There is air conditioning and ceiling fans in all the rooms and on the deck, so the temperature is well-controlled. The staff is very friendly and the breakfast was great. They also serve iced tea and cake in the afternoons, and wine/cheese on weekends. Warm-baked cookies and milk are served in the evening.We has a perfect time! I would highly recommend renting the Japser house for groups of 3 or more sleeping solo...it can accommodate up to eight but that would include bed-sharing.I loved this place and would definitely go again. You can have your own HOUSE for the price some of those high-end inns are charging for a room.**Couple things to be aware of : They have a few cats..really cute and sweet. They stay out on the decks, and in the courtyard, so you can avoid them easily if you are allergic or something.  Also, there are stairs to the front entrance and stairs to each floor...so if you are using one of the bedrooms on the third floor, you are doing quite a bit of stair-climbing.Sadly, I will never get to share the great experiences of the other Yelpers who stayed at this Inn. I pre-paid one night's rate to hold a reservation. When we had a conflict and had to postpone our travel, I promptly emailed the management to let them know the problem. Their reply was, "no problem, let us know when you will be traveling".  Seemed great, until they called me the night I was originally scheduled to stay, left a message asking where I was and when I contacted them in the AM, they told me my deposit was forfeited. Ugh. Anyone know of another awesome B&B in Savannah??!This was a nice place, and the people were very friendly. The location of the B&B was great. The breakfast was great and the people were great.We stayed in the Chatham room which was really quaint and looked out on Chatham Square. The decor was traditional and very pretty, and the bathroom was completely redone and modern. The only drawback was that the room was not really well insulated sound-wise, and when our neighbors were in their room next door, we could hear everything (in their bathroom anyway). But still, I would recommend this inn.This is a really good place to stay, the location is excellent...away from the touristy places yet not far from the historic district.The staff was very polite and helpful.We stayed at the tree top room which had a living room, kitchen and a bed room.You get the classic features of historic Savannah house without the haunting...lol.WHAT A GEM!!!  Yes, I had to put that in CAPITALS.  I found this place via a last minute internet search 2 weeks prior to my vacation to the East Coast.  I offer huge thanks to Google that they were all the way on top.  All of the other B&Bs were running over $200.00 for the week of June 25, but the boyfriend and I snagged a BEAUTIFUL Egyptian themed room for WAY under $200.00 because of a SUMMER SPECIAL that they were running.  Even without the special, the rates are a great deal.The breakfast was good and the sweet tea available during the afternoon tea was DELICIOUS.  We were pleased that the B&B offered free internet.  Plus, our room overlooked Chatham Sqare, which is lovely during the afternoon.The hotel is close to Forsyth Park (BEAUTIFUL) and is about a 15 minute stroll from the riverside.  Yet, hands down, this is one of the loveliest hotels that my boyfriend and I have stayed at.  The staff made us feel at home and I would definitely  stay here again, if given the chance!My husband and I recently were lucky enough to stay in the Cottage on the Lane, a converted carriage house that is part of the B&B. It was very private, and had a downstairs parlor and kitchen as well as a lovely bedroom upstairs. Everybody who worked at the Inn made sure we had a great time, and for the value, I think it would be hard to beat staying here. It is located in a more residential area, but walking to the more commercial parts of Savannah only takes around 10-15 minutes. The highlights of course were eating breakfast in the courtyard and grabbing chocolate chip cookies before bed at the end of the day. If we return to Savannah, we will be returning here as well.

review_content: Stayed here for two nights recently with the family and my daughter's soccer team for a tournament in town.  The lobby and breakfast area are nice, i really like the layout, pretty open.  They could use a little more seating, but otherwise good.  We had a double-queen room, it was in the corner near the stairs so I think it was a little larger than most of their rooms.  In any case, the rooms are fairly large with a separate sitting area and desk.  It's not totally isolated from the sleeping area, however, it's a little separate which makes it nice with kids who go to bed earlier.  The hotel is clean, modern, nicely decorated and the rooms are spacious and comfortable.  The location is pretty convenient to the historic district and restaurants, only a few blocks away, and in a reasonable neighborhood (some parts of Savannah are a little run-down and sketchy).  Would definitely stay here again.   Positives: Clean, modern hotel with a nice breakfast area and lobby.  Large rooms with 2 queen beds (not doubles) and pullout sofa.Negatives: Cold in the hallways.   Paper-mill smell in hallways sometimes, but rooms were fine always.This hotel is nice. The front desk staff has always been very accommodating. The valets are very friendly.   Sometimes there are strange things in the room like one washcloth  or one trashcan for the entire room but these are minor things. Hate to rate the hotel one star but the problem listed below clouds my judgment of this hotel chain. My big problem with Marriott as a company is the customer service of their rewards program. I have called several times to try to correct a problem that is falling on deaf ears. When I signed up for the rewards program I selected miles, unfortunately the airline that was associated with my account went out of business years ago. Once I realize the account was going towards miles versus points, I tried to get credit for the last couple of stays that have occurred within the last six months.   The customer service agents and the supervisors have all  chirped like a bird and said you have to deal with the airline. This must be a rehearsal line they cannot deviate from because they can't seem to understand that the airline is out of business. One supervisor offered to give me 1000 points, this is nowhere near credit for the four nights stay that I deserve.   The service that I have received from this department is the horrible.  I am a very reasonable person and do not ask for things that I do not deserve.Let me start by saying the concierge, the front desk staff, the breakfast staff deserve 6 stars, they were friendly and professional.  I am a faithful Marriott patron, I will drive 50 miles to stay at a Marriott if need be.  I checked into the Savannah Spring Hill Suites on Monday, February 23rd, scheduled to check out on Thursday, February 26th.  Due to a need to extend my stay, I contacted the hotel staff and made a separate reservation, checking in on the 26th, departing on the 27th.  The type of room I was in was not available for another night, so I was required to change rooms.The morning of the 26th, I was able to check my luggage with the front desk staff for retrieval later that day when I returned to check-in again and move to my new room.   The problem ensued the morning of the 27th, upon departure, I began to check my room to be sure I had all my belongings.  I sleep with socks on and they typically find themselves off my feet by morning.  So in usual fashion, I pulled the covers back to check for socks and found blood on my sheets.  I was immediately livid and sick to my stomach. I started to just write the staff a note and leave it at that until, I grabbed an unused towel and applied cold water to the towel.  I took the lightly moist towel and applied moisture to the largest spot of blood on the sheet.  The blood began to smear, letting me know this was not a stain that had been previously washed and unable to be removed from the sheets, this was a stain on sheets that had not been changed after another individual laid or slept on them. I took a picture of the sheets, with my date stamped record of stay.  There were three stains present on the sheet, to prove it was not my blood, I cut a portion of the area I applied the damp towel, in addition to the dry spot to the right of the photo frame.Upon checking out I spoke to the Front Desk personnel, in which the attempt to comp my stay and/or provide points would suffice for this egregious violation.  I responded I did not want my stay credited nor the points; and at that time I was unsure of my course of action, but would be in touch.  To date, the only communication since my departure has been with my attorney. I have not been contacted by anyone from the hotel, even after contacting Corporate.  I have never in all my life experienced such disgusting practices.  I have traveled domestically and abroad this experience has forever damaged my ability to place trust in the hospitality industry and their regulated or lack thereof sanitary practices.I have tried several hotels in the Savannah area. The Courtyard Savannah Downtown/Historic District -- nothing great and the rooms vary wildly in experience. The Hilton Savannah DeSoto -- more of a landmark than a great hotel experience and expensive as well. Then while walking around the downtown Savannah area, and being bumped once again trying to get out of town, I decided to give this place a try.I am really glad I did. The pricing is great and everything feels new -- not only literally but also in the slick design of the suites. For me this was a huge step forward from the other places I have tried and there is no downside on the location. Great for exploring downtown on foot from the front door and still a nice location for everything to do with SCAD.Newly renovated and looks like it. Very nice lobby, modern with sweeping curves; room was clean with an extra sink/toilet room; bed good (a great mattress earns a fifth star); location walking distance to all shops and restaurants. Valet parking handy and the attendant, Vincent was engaging.Ok, Pros: Location. Right in the middle of the historic district, walking distance to a lot of cool places. Beds. They have one of the best hotel beds we've had, and we've stayed in plenty, and that's big for us.The layout. The bathroom and the toilet area are  separate, which is a big plus, especially when traveling with more people. Staff. Very friendly and helpful. Price was reasonable and included free breakfast. Now, cons: The layout. Yes, it is both in pros and cons. The room seemed small and the layout was a littler awkward, wasn't too much privacy allowed in the bathrooms, everything could be heard. Not much room to walk around either. The comforter for the sofa bed had what looked like a burned stain, wasn't happy about that. Breakfast left much to be desired, weren't too many choices, coffee was ok, but good thing they had a waffle station. So, to sum up, 3 stars as had too many cons for me, and I'm usually good with giving out stars, but I guess should be expected, considering the price, which WAS good, compared to other hotels in the area.It is still good to keep this location in mind, maybe will give it another try.This hotel is about a 5 minute walk from where the action is.  I spent almost a month here and I really enjoyed this place, the staff is very nice the rooms are clean and there is a nice heated pool. The only drawback (IMO) is that they force you to valet park. Rather than waiting for someone to bring me my car I opted to walk to the public parking one street over. While I don't mind paying for parking, I hate having to wait for my car. The other issue was that the hotel seems to always be filled with kids that crowd the breakfast buffet in the morning - nothing against them, but I did have to go elsewhere for breakfast several times because there was no room in the area. Overall the staff though made up for the minor shortcomings and I would definitely stay here again.Pros - Clean room, clean hotel in general. Super comfy bed! Very nice staff. Warm poolCons - Slow wifi. REALLY hard water with a strong sulphur smell. I can't be the first person to tell them this. There was a white film left on my skin after the shower and my skin felt dry. My hair was crunchy after washing it AND even still after using a deep conditioner in the shower. You need to install water filtration/softeners on your sinks and showerheads. I'm from NYC where the water is very soft so I'm definitely not used to it.Industrial cleaner odor, bathroom door broken, lumpy beds and shower faucet that needs a strong arm to turn on. Disappointed.in the process of renovation, but still comfortable and clean with plenty of space for a family of 6. front desk was very helpful with suggestions for restaurants etc in the area.This is a new location (for me anyway) in Savannah's Historic District.The lobby is huge and slightly inviting, IF there's someone to greet you at the desk semi-centered in the room. The concierge area/desk is a little odd in that the concierge is actually seated behind a desk. There are no chairs for guests to be seated while having a conversation with the concierge but that could be strategic in that they don't want/anticipate the guests to linger. Complimentary breakfast offered, We didn't partake so I can't offer a review of the offerings. Overall, the hotel is clean. Our room was clean and had the basics (microwave and refrigerator, beds).  I did like the toilet area being totally separate from the shower/tub area. that was a plus especially when traveling with women. the location was perfect walking distance to everything in the area (River Street, City Center, Henry's, and shopping).We are planning to keep this one in mind when planning visits to Savannah.#tellingyouwhatithink #dpursuitisrealChecked in on a Thursday for a long weekend, Government discount took care of the 20 dollar fee each day for valet. Valet service was very efficient. The hotel itself is in a great location, helpful friendly staff, free breakfast and great free 24 hour coffee stand. Room was very clean, tv is in an odd location (but it swivels) bed was not the most comfortable however sufficient and bathroom/shower lay out is a bit odd. Overall great value for your money and if we ever get back down to Savannah, GA we will stay here again!Spacious room and friendly staff.  Microwave and fridge nice to have.  Great shower.  Valet was prompt and courtesy.   Walking distance to various attractions.  Potential areas of improvement: stains on floor and ceiling, bottle of whiskey bottle (1/3 full) in closet (??!?), slide door of toilet area (shower is in a different room) did not fitted properly against wall so gap doesn't allow for privacy, only two small drawers in closet so unable to unpack luggage, charge for using wireless phone if more than two devices, parking fees.Overall the stay was nice but a few things bugged me as we stayed here.  First off, housekeeping seems to think everyone staying there wakes up at the crack of dawn.  We live on the West Coast, so when they were banging on our door to clean the room at 830 in the morning, it was 530 to us.  A few of the days, I did not get to the door fast enough to tell them to come back later and she just used her key to barge right in.  I explained our situation but each morning we were awoken by housekeeping at a VERY early hour. On a positive note, they were VERY friendly.I also did not like the lay out of the bathrooms.  With the type of sliding door that they had, if anyone was laying on the far bed, they got a good view of you doing your business.....just what someone wants to see on vacation.  Same with the shower. The TV was also off to the side in a very odd location, so if you were laying in bed you had to turn your neck to see the TV...you don't see that often in hotels. I also didn't like that valet was your only option here.  We were there visiting family, some living there and some staying at other hotels so we were out an about a lot and it was very inconvenient to have to get your car out of valet each time you leave, not to mention pricey as you have to tip the valet attendant each time in addition to the parking cost.   The room was very clean and the staff were all very friendly.  If not for those small issues, I would have been 100% happy, but waking papa bear up too early does not make for a good day, just ask the kids.Overall a very pleasant stay. They room was clean and quiet- my top two requirements for a hotel. Staff was mostly good but service could be slow at times. Its location can't be beat and for a reasonable cost. In March (spring break) we paid $139/night and were only minutes away from most anywhere we wanted to go in the historic district.The pool was small but clean and the hot tub inviting. The breakfast was an absolute waste of time unless you drag yourself out of bed early before the rush. We learned that after the first morning. We ended up downstairs by 9:30am and found every serving tray scraped clean. The only thing left was something that resembled ham. It was the most disgusting shade of grey- I guess no one wanted to eat that! The following mornings we were downstairs by 8am and had no trouble getting grub. Food was blah- but it was free. Oh, and they had grits, which was a nice way to warm up on a chilly morning. With so many great dining choices in Savannah we'd eat just enough at the hotel to tide us over until we ate lunch by 11am. The room itself is a little odd. The toilet and shower are in two separate "rooms" with pocket doors. The toilet room is about the size of a closet. The entire room is very narrow and laid out in a shotgun arrangement. The frosted door of the shower "room" isn't very practical. The separate seating area has a pull out couch. It was a tight squeeze for 2 adults and 2 kids. But overall we had a nice visit and wouldn't hesitate to stay here again.I absolutely loved this place.. Service was impeccable, rooms were clean and up to par, valet was on point. We stayed for valentines 2014 and had an excellent view of the city from floor 6. Although it's not exactly walking distance from downtown, well atleast not if you're wearing heels. It's still pretty close. I recommend trying to book through Hotwire or Travelocity as the at desk price can be a bit high. Average price is about 180. If you want something special though it's worth every bit of it. Two thumbs upThe lobby was open and clean. Parking is valet only unless you find street parking on your own. I would not count on street parking. The location is nice and allows easy access to much of Savannah. The layout of our room was strange. The television was inconveniently placed and the toilet and shower were in different, unconnected rooms. There was free wifi which worked well for light internet browsing. Our room had a nice view of the south side of town.Great location and very nice and helpful staff members.  Everything is very close, good breakfast and very clean. Rooms aren't as big as i expected but nothing else found offers any better. Free internet is slower and cant be used for Netflix.First of all I am definitely a fan of Marriott hotels. I am a silver elite member and probably stay in 10-12 Marriotts a year. In fact this is what I told the manager when I complained to him. This Marriott was ok but not up to Marriott's tip top standards.1. Walked in to find the pool was closed down -- the 1st week in Aug.?? Good planning there. The manager told me it was Marriott's fault not that hotel -- I said well at least they could have told me a head of time. 2. Then they put us in one room and then asked us to move so they could deep clean the room we were in. Ok, no problem - we moved.3. I thought the desk staff was slow. As I paid more attention the lady working there, alone, was an intern. 4. We loved the guys in valet parking - they were super friendly but once it was raining so we asked if they could call us a cab. They said the front desk would do it -- as you can guess slow front desk, we waited a while and then just ended up walking.5. The breakfast and breakfast area was good. 6. Location was great and super convenient for walking!7. I see some others complained about the cleaning staff waking them early. They over compensated. Our room was not cleaned by 2:30 pm and we really needed some towels to take showers. My daughter called and asked and they said some one would be up. After 30 min. I went down the hall and just grabbed some off the cart. 8. I did personally complain to the manager and while he seemed nice he didn't really have any solutions other than summer is busy. He asked me several times what could he do for me. I wasn't going to demand my money back as the situation was not that drastic -- after the 3rd time he asked I said - "well you can give me some extra Marriott points". I am guessing he forgot because that never happened. I know I sound like a complainer but this is not a bad hotel it is just not up to Marriott's usual excellent standards!Great location! And So relieved to be at Spring Hill Suites that I give it 4stars just for having room to accommodate my friend & I last minute. Small, cozy room & fresh, clean & modern. PLUS no yard cockroaches like at the place we checked out at here in Savannah (where I also was robbed by the housekeeping staff). Whirlpool & pool are outside so it's nice but sucks when it rains.
review_content_20: It's not the Ritz, but I would never stay anywhere in Savannah than this hotel. Staff awesome. Location perfect.Suites extremly comfortable. Fitness center great for cardio only.Breakfast typical when it's free.Very reasonably priced.. When traveling south for the winter, this is the best place to stay for a couple of nights.The SpringHill Suites hotel is an awesome place to stay while you're in the beautiful city of Savannah!  It's such a modern hotel within such a vintage city.The standard two queen bedroom was pretty roomy - there's a living/office area with a couch, cute coffee tables, and a desk area that is divided from the bedroom area.  There are two "bathrooms" - one toilet room with a sink (which had no counterspace) and one shower room with a sink (which had plenty of counterspace - which is a must have for me!)One weird thing about the room is that the flat screen tv is situated off to the side of the first bed - yes, the tv can swivle so you can watch tv while you're in bed, but it's just in a weird spot.Valet parking is available for $15 per day, the hotel provides breakfast in the lobby, and wifi is available for free.  The best part is that this hotel is walking distance from everything!  Very convenient location, great furnishings, and good customer service.  I would definitely come back to this hotel if I'm ever in Savannah again!This hotel is nice-looking, modern, sleek, and mostly fine. But I'm only giving it three stars, and here's why:(1) the television was in an awkward position askew from both beds;(2) the water closet (toilet) had a sliding door with no lock, a noticeable gap (you can see the person inside), and basically no privacy whatsoever;(3) the lighting was too dim, and the light between the beds made a terribly loud buzzing noise;(4) the microwave and refrigerator were placed in an awkward place and not very easy to use.It's basically a nice hotel, but I felt that the room had a weird layout, and there were just a few irritating things that make me give it three stars.Spinghill Suites Marriott treat customers this poorly???  Buyer beware!$20 per day mandatory valet parking.  Nothing else available.I chose to stay here because the website indicates parking is an amenity next to many free amenities.  This is very misleading because no self-parking is possible, and the only option is $20/day for mandatory valet.When I brought this to the attention of management, Paige rudely refused to ameliorate the website or the misrepresentation. This after she thanked me for my platinum status. I immediately switched to the Marriott Riverfront and recommend you do the same!Additionally, Paige (Springhill Management) said she would charge me 1 night to switch my reservation.  Marriott customer service waived the fee and said there would be no charge.  As someone who stays at Marriotts weekly for business travel, this hotel has the worst management I've seen since in over 10 years.A terrible experience. I booked the hotel after reading the rave yelp reviews, so I'm guess my horrible experience was an isolated one, but here goes...Called about an hour before we arrived to make a reservation. Spelled out my name, gave my credit card, etc.  Then when we arrived, they didn't have it.  The girl at the front desk said they had no more rooms, so there was no way I possibly could have made a reservation. I asked her to call the corporate reservation line and instead she proceeded to help other guests behind me. After about 20 minutes of this, I asked her what the status was and she said she wasn't sure. Flabbergasted, I said forget it and found another place to stay.A week later, I noticed they charged my credit card. I called the hotel, they told me to call reservations, who told me to call the hotel. I flipped my lid and the person at reservations advised me she would "send an email to see if they would refund me". I nearly flipped my lid again, but said ok. Fortunately, someone at the hotel who didn't have their head in their arse contacted me immediately and refunded me the money. Looks like they had my reservation and couldn't locate it because my name was spelled incorrectly. But, how they were still able to charge my card, I have no idea.My best friend and I rolled into Savannah without a plan, or a hotel reservation.  After calling around we had booked an affordable room at a hotel about 10 miles from downtown, but as we made our way in that direction we decided that location was more important than cost.  We decided we would much rather stay one night downtown than two far away.  We called the SpringHill Suites and I could not be happier with this decision.We walked in to the hotel 30 seconds after booking the room with reservations and Tatiyana was able to get us in our room right away.  We pulled into the valet and all the adorable boys were friendly and willing to lend a helping hand.  That sounds like reverse order, but it is actually how it worked out...don't dwell.The room was GORGEOUS!  Clean and crisp are the best words to describe it.  The cool tones, and inviting pillows just enticed me to relax.  We got ourselves together and decided to go for a walk around.  A couple of walking drinks later and we made our way back to the hotel.We were having such a great time already that we wanted to extend our stay, if possible, despite the cost.  Well, Tatiyana not only was able to extend our stay, but also gave us a great rate for the second night.  OH THE SAVINGS!!!Joy at the concierge desk was a delicious delight and exactly what you would want from a person in her position at a hotel in a city like Savannah.Complementary Hot breakfast in the ultra-modern lounge each morning was lovely, even considering all the little gymnasts taking over the waffle maker.I give this hotel high praise and plan to use it every time I visit Savannah, and given how much I loved it...that may be quite a bit.Wow. I wrote a very detailed and unfavorable yet accurate review complete with photos yesterday and they took it off the yelp site. Shady !!!! They don't have a bartender and the bar food came out of plastic bags from the local quick mart.  Savages!!!The lobby was the best thing about this place. I wasn't a fan of the room layout and the pocket-door bathrooms.K and I were back in Savannah and the SpringHill Suites was again our base of operations. Right on Oglethorpe and Montgomery, any place you want to go is a pleasant few blocks' walk, and walk we did. Despite being a year older, the hotel still feels fresh, bright, and inviting. The valet service for the truck was prompt and polite, the front desk staff helpful. The room was as lovely as last year. K found the mattress to be especially restful, and the internet service (free to me as a Marriotts Rewards member) was fast and reliable.I honestly don't know how they could improve on their accommodations or service. Five-star all the way.Great modern designed hotel in a perfect Savannah location.Very friendly and accommodating front desk staff who helped us find our way around for the weekend we were here.You can easily walk to many restaurants. If you're a beer drinker head over to The Distillery which is very close to this hotel.The rooms were modern and inviting and the bed was comfortable. We enjoyed the pool (along with 900 girl scouts) a few times and that was a nice feature.I would definitely come back to this hotel whenever I'm back in Savannah.Loved the location and the experience.  Excellent valet parking ($20), beautiful room, plush bedding and towels, great room layout.  A smooth experience for a weary traveller.Location makes it easy to leave your car and walk the downtown and river areas.  Also, easy access back to 95.  Safe, convenient, and accommodating.Great location. The historic district is within walking distance. The valet service is good. The front desk staff was very friendly and helpful. The room is awesome, but I echo the concerns about the TV being in an awkward spot (not a big deal for me, though). My family and I swam in the heated pool on New Year's Day. Great experience.We checked in with my family on The hotel is great, clean, new, free wifi, free breakfast, jacuzzi and heated pool.We loved it, the staff was very friendly, Katie at the front desk, Lauren  was helping us with the breakfast and Austin was a great concierge.Why I'm giving 4 starts and not 5 is because I didn't see any single recycling beans, no Recycling Other than that the Hotel is great and the staff is vey friendlyA nice surprise.We stayed here for 4 nights in mid-May for a wedding in town.  Loved the atmosphere of the hotel (fun boutique) and the location (walking distance to pretty much everything).  The rooms were clean and smoke free.  The bed was comfortable to sleep on for 4 nights straight (well except for the night I passed out on the floor).  And being a tall guy, I'm always excited to be able to stand up in the shower.Stacie F., I shared a your terrible experience. Here goes or review! Unfortunately Marriott Reservations screwed up our reservation, when we arrived to the hotel with two infants, their parents and great grandparents (85 and 87) we found out that we only had  two of the three rooms reserved. Mr. Bill "WT" Wade, manager, refused to assist us either to locate another room for us or calling their sister facilities for us to accommodate our family. Contrary, he recommended several times that because we bothered his day with our request, we should not stay in this hotel. Well I'm a Marriott Rewards customer and we were using Marriott points, I wonder if Mr. WT, wanted to make more money with somebody. Wow, lousy way to treat loyal customers. F.C.Location is very convenient, staff very friendly and professional.  Room cleanliness leaves something to be desired, stained furniture and carpet, not vacuumed during our 3 day stay,It was clean, period.  Everything else did not work.  The remote did not work-it needed new batteries.  We were promised for over 24 hours that an "engineer" would be up to replace those batteries.  After 3 calls and 2 days, nobody showed up.  Our door cards also did not work more than once.  4 times we had to go down to the desk to get them "fixed." That is very frustrating.  The girl said that she would have the "engineer" look at the door lock.  Hope was it not the same engineer who was supposed to change the batteries in our remote.  The breakfast was really blah and bland and for most of the time I was there was out of several items.  Valet parking was expensive.  Would not go back because service/price did not match.I'm a fan of Marriott even being an Elite Rewards Member.  I had a couple of free nights to use for a category 1-4 hotel.  Our options in the historic district  were this one or Courtyard by Marriott.  We selected this one mainly because of the free breakfast.  The hotel and rooms are modern, even more trendy than the NYC Marriott we stayed at last summer.  The rooms were average size for a hotel but slightly small for a suite.  They had a fridge and microwave which was awesome.  The standup shower was very nice as well, and the toilet room was separate in case someone's taking a shower and you need to go.  There is a nice little work station with a divider from the sleeping area.  It's Marriott, so internet access (hardwire or wireless) is free.  They have an outdoor heated pool and jacuzzi but we didn't have time to go.  The breakfast was standard Marriott.  Eggs, turkey sausage, grits, oatmeal, cereal, juice, coffee, toast, fruit, muffins, and make your own waffles.  I did notice their sanitation grade was 83 which is low, but that's likely because of all of the things like bread left out in the open.The hotel is walking distance to everything in the district this side of Bull St.  The Distillery, a craft beer bar, is around the corner.  This was nice because you can get "to go" drinks in Savannah.  The walk down Montgomery into the heart of the district was fine, but when we walked down Bay St it was a little sketchier.  River St, City Market, Telfair Museum, the Civic Center, the Lady and Sons, and more are all nearby.  The parking is valet only for $15 (typical for Savannah) but there also is a city parking garage next door that could be cheaper.I'd say if you get the right price for this hotel to stay at it.  It's a nice hotel with many amenities and is close to almost everything.The modern designs were interesting. Reminded me of south Florida,  intense greens and blues, bright lighting. But the rooms are nice with a sofa area and desk, flat panel TV, and comfortable beds with a lot of pillows. This location is close to the top of Bay Street. With ample places to eat. Just be sure to wear your sun glasses when you enter, otherwise you will be blinded by the neon green.Very modern. I love the design and suite set up. I have stayed in the double bed suite and king bed suite. Both are extremely room and all of the amenities one could ask for. The staff is courteous and attentive to guest needs, plus they have a concierge service. This is my second time back here and I will definitely make it a third.
review_content_40: This is a great location. The staff was very helpful. The beds were extra comfy; I asked for special pillows on the Marriott website and they did not disappoint. The decor is modern and ... interesting. The mirror in the bathroom is not your friend if you have body image issues. It's two mirrors in one - a circular mirror mounted to the wall mirror. (See the picture for a better idea.) The circular mirror doesn't fog, but it does distort your body! LOL, I had fun jumping around in the bathroom and watching myself go from short to tall.The breakfast, as far as free hotel breakfast goes, was awesome! They also have free coffee and tea all day. The only real complaint I had was the vents in our room. The bathroom vent started banging every morning at 6 a.m. The only way to make it stop was to turn on the light and leave the fan running. It stopped around ten. I didn't tell the front desk because it wasn't that big of a deal, but I'll leave a note on the comment card so they can look into the issue.All in all, made for a great "home base" in Savannah.Some friends and I were in Savannah for New Year's Eve 2011 and stayed at this new SpringHill Suites for a couple of nights. Thinking ahead and booking in advance saved us a few bucks on the room, and it's a good thing we did -- they had one open room left when we arrived that was going for a pretty high price (eavesdropping at the front desk, sleuth mode). While a relatively new property, the "modern" designs were...interesting. Reminded me a bit of South Beach -- super intense greens and blues, bead curtains, bright fluorescent lighting. But the rooms are nice with a sofa/seating area and desk, flat panel TV, modern appointments in the bathroom and toilet, and comfortable beds with ample pillows. Our room was never cleaned by house keeping. After the first night, we were still in the room when they came by to clean, and they never came back. We had to hit up the front desk a couple of times for clean towels. Boo. But it's not like we're slobs, so it wasn't horrible to not have the beds made up for our spoiled asses. This location is not a bad walk to the top of Bay Street and/or River Street. I'd stay here again, if my eyes can get past the neon greens.I just returned from a 3 night stay at the SpringHill Suites in Savannah downtown, and I would certainly recommend it to anyone looking for a spacious room near all the sights of Savannah.We were 4 women travelling for Girl's weekend, and we legit got everything we needed from this hotel: spacious room with a separate sitting area, check; walking distance to all the sights without any of the noise of the busier River or Bay streets, check; complimentary continental breakfast with a really good spread PLUS amazing coffee, check; great pool and hot tub area, perfect for relaxing in after a long day of walking and sight seeing, check.We had a few minor hiccups, like no towels at the pool, but these were brought up to us as soon as we called.  All the employees we dealt with were very friendly and helpful, which was a big (albeit not unexpected, as we are in the south) plus for us.  We did have a few rouge charges on our bill prior to checking out, but they were removed right away upon us calling them to the hotel's attention. Other than that, we had an excellent time at the SpringHill Suites, and would definitely recommend it to all types of travelers to Savannah.I wish I could rate this hotel higher. I just wasn't impressed overall. Let me start with the good points. The hotel is newer and gorgeous. The rooms look just like they do in the pictures, which was refreshing. The rooms were spacious too; the beds were SUPER comfy!! We stayed in a room with my husband's parents. The toilet is in its own water closet, which is convenient. Our room rate also included breakfast which was basic and tasty. The location is right off the expressway so the hotel was easy to find. The front desk clerk was very friendly, knowledgeable and helpful. He recommended a spot for cocktails that overlooked the river and the entire city. The "eh" points were that our shower was very slow to drain. I called to have the repairman come but when he did my father in law was in the shower. We asked that he return in a few minutes, but the repairman never showed. Also, there was a large wet spot outside of the bathroom caused by a leak of some sort from the shower tub. I expected better conditions from a new hotel. The water closet was not private at all. Since we were sharing a room it made for an uncomfortable "potty" situation. You heard EVERYTHING that went on in the water closet. The door was only a sliding door, so it didn't even offer you much in the way of visual privacy. I'm not sure if I would stay here again. One review states that they paid less than $100 for their room. We paid over $100. I guess we don't need all the fancy decor as we don't spend a lot of time in our room when we travel. If we paid less than $100 I would most likely stay there again. Overall it was a nice, decent, safe place to stay. I just wouldn't recommend sharing a room as it doesn't offer much in the way of bathroom privacy...which I guess is important to me.We spent one night here and would quite gladly stay again. The room was large and clean - we lucked into a corner room giving us windows on two walls - and very quiet. There were a bunch of folks eating the free breakfast with us but the cool design of the dining area makes it seem at least somewhat intimate. This is the third tome we've stayed at a SpringHill Suites in the past six months and we are fans. Recommended!Enjoyed this hotel. It was located within walking distance to a lot of the restaurants, bars and shops in the Savannah area.  The hotel was decorated nicely for the Christmas season and the room was very modern and large.  The toilet was separate from the shower, which was kind of different, but was helpful for a group of 5 girls all trying to get ready at the same time. The staff was helpful and kind.  The price of the hotel was very good.  Free breakfast is included.Great location in historic district.  Rooms were spacious and well equipped.  Staff was very approachable and friendly.  The gym was also surprisingly stocked considering that Springhill is on the lower end of the Marriott brands.  Free breakfast and wifi also a huge plus.  Downside: strange smell in hallway at times and the rooms also have that signature hotel deodorant smell.Super nice hotel located just far enough away from the craziness on the river.  They let me check in at 10am, which really helped me out, as i had to get ready for a wedding.  Parking is expensive, but we parked on the street or there is a parking garage right next door for much less.  They also have a very nice breakfast in the morning, and it's only a 5 minute walk to the river.  I will definitely be staying here next time i come to savannah.Stayed here with the whole family for one night, just stopping over in Savannah on a road trip.  The place was immaculate, rooms very modern but practical, great breakfast buffet. And it was affordable - less than $100 a night. Highly recommended if you are traveling and looking for a clean hotel.So far, so great!!! We checked in yesterday and will be here for a couple more days. The nite staff is super nice! Day staff is a little stiff. The rooms are wonderful and clean. Breakfast was good this morning except too many kids taking too many cream cheese cups and bananas but that has nothing to do with the hotel, it's called lack of supervision by parents. I did inform the desk about the lack and they called the kitchen staff to replenish. The lobby area is gorgeous! Free (good) coffee available 24/7!New hotel suites that are clean, modern, and affordable.  Free Breakfast heated pool/jacuzzi, large gym, and friendly staff.  Hotel is on the corner of Montgomery and Oglethorpe just a few short blocks from City Market (which starts at the Franklin Square) and River Street in the heart of Savannah's Historic District.This hotel was a mess.  It gets a star for its location, which is walking distance to things in the historic part of Savannah. The hotel gets only one star, because of the way it handled my reservation.  I had booked it months prior to my stay, and specified that I needed a crib and a tub.  The hotel put it in my notes, and then told me I needed to call the week of my reservation.  I did this three days before my reservation, and again they put it in my notes - assuring me that I would have the crib.  They asked that I call back the day before check-in, which I did.  I called and the lady said she would block the room and set up the crib.  When we checked in (around 1 am), the room lacked the tub and the crib.  The guy at the front desk had no knowledge of the room with the crib, nor were there any cribs available. We were transferred to a room equipped for disabled folks as it had a tub.  And, even after staying for 4 days -- no crib.  I tried to book at another hotel and the whole area was sold out.   I would have bought a crib, but had a weekend full of wedding events and did not have time to try to find a target in an area I did not know.Great hotel!!! Friendly staff!!! Very helpful! They recommended lots of places to eat and sights to see!! Hot breakfast! Big rooms with a separate sitting area with a built in desk. The only weird thing was the toilet was not in the bathroom with the shower. There were 2 separate rooms a shower and sink in one and toilet and sink in another. But it was very modern!!! Loved if!!! Big wardrobe to store clothes...  With Extra pillows in it!! I am already planning my next stay here!!!!Pretty good location, very walkable to River Front.  Was able to check in early (thanks!), but they do allow you to store your luggage if check in not yet available.  Not too many restaurants/bars around the hotel, so plan on going out.  Breakfast buffet included, but nothing extensive.  Consider avoiding the rooms on 2nd floor that are pool-side; the noise (people and hot tub bubbling) does affect the rooms, and the black out curtains do not black out.   Pool is very empty in the morning, so get up early and enjoy.  It may still be locked, however, so call the Front Desk and remind them.This is, by far and away, the best SpringHill Suites, and probably the best hotel in downtown Savannah.  This place makes me feel as if I am in the midst of the chic, young and sexy crowd.
